tags.bio: Adrian Searle has been art critic for the Guardian since 1996. Trained as a painter, he began writing in 1976 for Artscribe magazine and continues to contribute to art magazines and journals. His publications include a recent Phaidon monograph on Peter Doig (2007). He has curated several exhibitions in the UK, Europe and the USA, including shows for the Hayward in 1994 and the Reina Sofia in Madrid in 2003. Most recently he curated the first retrospective of Brazilian sculptor Lucia Nogueira (1950-98), for the Serralves Museum in Porto, Portugal. He was a Turner Prize juror in 2004. Searle has taught at many art colleges in Britain and Europe and is currently a visiting professor at the Royal College of Art in London.

webTitle: Running blog: picture of the day

fields.standfirst:
These days barely 12 hours pass by without an organised run somewhere, but back in 1977 in Gateshead it was a trailblazing event. Organised by Brendan Foster, fresh from trips to America and New Zealand, the event lasted 20 minutes. If you hadn't run your two miles in that time, you had to stop. But if you were part of that event and didn't make it over the line, fear not: Foster wants you to come back and finish.

More information at greatrun.org

tags.bio:
Eric Allison is the Guardian's prison correspondent.

He was born in Manchester, 1942, the youngest of four boys. His first conviction was for housebreaking when he was 11 and, at 14, he received his first custodial sentence. Three months in a detention centre was intended to provide a "short sharp shock" to deter him but instead he met up with virtually every member of the "class of 57" during his criminal/penal journey, which ended in 2000. Eric Allison has spent some 16 years in prison, all for theft related offences. During that time he quickly became appalled at the bad treatment handed out to people who had not "chosen" crime as a career and witnessed acts of brutality and racism on an almost daily basis. As a result he decided to speak out and took action against the abuse. He discovered that the adage "the pen is mightier … " proved particularly accurate in prison and, following the Strangeways Prison Riot, in 1990, he co-authored a book on the protest, A Serious Disturbance. The book was used by several education authorities as A-level course work (Sociology). In 2003 Eric Allison joined the Guardian as the prison correspondent.

webTitle: Beautiful Games: drag-racing fever

fields.standfirst: Through clouds of pungent smoke and across shimmering salt flats, New Zealand born photographer Simon Davidson has painted a beguiling portrait of drag racing. Shooting at races in Australia and on the eerie, crystallised plains of Bonneville in Utah, Davidson has captured alluring images which numb stereotypical notions of motor-sport. There's something particularly cinematic about the scenes at Bonneville; the vintage vehicles and the pallid colours are suffused with nostalgia, while the motionlessness and detail within each frame are acutely observed. Images 13 and 19 look rather like stills from Vincent Gallo's The Brown Bunny. Even Davidson's pictures of burn-outs - the very epitome of wild, boorish behaviour - retain a certain tranquility; despite the chaotic intentions of the drivers, the engulfing smoke forms a beautifully ambient stage.
fields.headline: Beautiful Games: drag racing fever
fields.trailText: Simon Davidson's obsession for hot-rods has led him to create a beguiling portrait of drag racing

webTitle: Guardian Camera Club: Gethin Thomas' portfolio

fields.standfirst:
A review of Gethin Thomas' portfolio.

'Moat Lane Car Park' is so full of detail and texture, that single street lamp is the perfect compositional device; 'Cotswold Landscape' directs our eye via the point of focus, to the texture of the characteristic local stone. 'Palace Theatre Redditch' includes so much curtain that it gives a different perspective to a familiar stage set. The toning colours of 'Redditch Town Hall' combine perfectly with the repetitive lines and shapes; 'Vacant Shop' is more vivid, the sky combining with the weathered shop front. Clean and perfectly constructed, 'Runway' has a simple formality. A quirky eye is at work here
fields.headline: Guardian Camera Club: Gethin Thomas' portfolio

webTitle: Falcão and Renan score beautiful futsal goal – video

fields.standfirst: Brazilian futsal star Falcão hits a sublime rabona pass allowing Orlandia team-mate Renan to finish off a beautiful team goal against Palmeiras. After a neat pass from Renan is returned back to him by an Orlandia player, Renan dummies and runs on towards goal. Falcão receives the ball and clips it over the Palmeiras defence. Renan's run is perfectly timed and he volleys the ball home. It's not the first amazing goal involving Falcão – here he is scoring an innovative free-kick
